persons.name: MilesBland
persons.description: Anglican clergyman and mathematician. FRSL.

persons.name: RichardKnight
persons.description: Brother of George who were both scientific instrument makers based in Foster Lane, Cheapside, London.

persons.name: JohnNewman
persons.description: Scientific instrument maker of Lisle Street, and afterwards of Regent-street. Instrument maker to the Royal Institution who made the earliest Davy safety lamps.

places.name: 9 Lisle Street, London
places.description: Premises of the instrument maker John Newman.

persons.name: WilliamPayne
persons.description: Davy's laboratory assistant at the Royal Institution 1803-1813. His dismissal, for fighting, paved the way for Faraday's appointment in his place. His dates of birth and death are not known.

places.name: Bateman's Buildings, Soho Square
places.description: Bateman's Buildings formed part of the connection between Soho Square and Bateman Street in London. This may have been an address for Davy's laboratory assistant William Payne.

persons.name: MichaelFaraday
persons.description: From 1812 Davy used Faraday as his amanuensis and the following year secured his appointment as laboratory assistant at the Royal Institution. Despite a difficult relationship with Davy, Faraday later became the dominent figure at the Royal Institution and one of the leading scientific personalities of the middle third of the nineteenth century. FRSL.

persons.name: NicolasClément
persons.description: French chemist who worked with his father-in-law, Charles Desormes.

persons.name: William HydeWollaston
persons.description: Originally a physician he became a prominent chemist, physicist and physiologist isolating the chemical elements osmium, palladium and rhodium. He made his fortune by developing a method of obtaining metallic platinum. A friend and to some extent a rival of Davy's, in 1820 he served briefly as President of the Royal Society of London between Banks's death and Davy's election. FRSL.

persons.name: CharlesBlagden
persons.description: Physician who kept a revealing diary for most of his life. A friend of Joseph Banks serving as a Secretary of the Royal Society of London, 1784-1797; Knighted 1792. FRSL

persons.name: HenryWarburton
persons.description: A member of the Animal Chemistry Club, the Chemical Club, and the Geological Society of London, and a sporting friend of Davy's. FRSL.

persons.name: John Frederick WilliamHerschel
persons.description: Son of William Herschel and a ploymathic mathematician, natural philosopher, astronomer and chemist who coined the word photograph. Unsuccesful in being elected President of the Royal Society of London, he later became Master of the Mint. FRSL.

persons.name: Frederick WilliamHerschel
persons.description: Hanoverian astronomer and composer who while living in Bath discovered the planet later named Uranus. Moving to Slough he built the world's largest telescope to date which Davy visited when he was courting Jane Apreece. FRSL.

persons.name: HenryCavendish
persons.description: A central figure in English natural philosophy and chemistry, among other research he determined the density of the earth and discovered what would later be named hydrogen. He was one of the people who helped appoint Davy to the Royal Institution. Following his death in 1810 Davy delivered a widely-quoted eulogy on Cavendish and later arranged for some of his apparatus to be transferred to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

persons.name: Francois ReneCuraudau
persons.description: French pharmacist and chemist.

persons.name: LuigiGalvani
persons.description: Italian surgeon and anatomist who carried out experiments with electricity and animals. The term 'galvanism' was named after him

persons.name: Marcus AtiliusRegulus
persons.description: Roman statesman and general who was a consul of the Roman Republic in 267 BC and 256 BC. Much of his career was spent fighting the Carthaginians during the first Punic War.

persons.name: Jean-FrançoisBerger
persons.description: Swiss natural philosopher and physician with interests in geology,natural history, and physiology.

persons.name: Allen & Howard
persons.description: The partnership of William Allen (1770-1843) and Luke Howard (1772-1864), from whom Davy bought chemicals and apparatus.

persons.name: Claude LouisBerthollet
persons.description: French Chemist. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: William HaseldinePepys
persons.description: Pepys was a surgical and scientific instrument maker and chemist. Constructed large batteries used by Davy (amongst others). FRSL.

persons.name: CharlesDesormes
persons.description: Desormes was a French physicist and chemist. He did most of his scientific work in collaboration with his son-in-law, Nicolas Clément.

persons.name: WilliamNicholson
persons.description: Founding editor of A Journal of Natural Philosophy, Chemistry, and the Arts (1797-1814) where Davy published some of his early papers. Part of the Godwin circle.

persons.name: Louis BernardGuyton de Morveau
persons.description: French chemist and revolutionary politician who is credited with producing the first systematic method of chemical nomenclature. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: NicolasClément
persons.description: French chemist who worked with his father-in-law, Charles Desormes.

persons.name: RichardKirwan
persons.description: Irish chemist, mineralogist and geologist who accused fellow geologist, James Hutton, of athiesm following publication of his Theory of the Earth (1788). FRSL

persons.name: WilliamAllen
persons.description: Allen was a Quaker who worked in the pharmaceutical industry. Davy asked him to give lectures on natural philosophy at the RI. FRSL.

persons.name: RichardKnight
persons.description: Brother of George who were both scientific instrument makers based in Foster Lane, Cheapside, London.

places.name: Grand Surrey Canal
places.description: A canal constructed in south London in the early nineteenth century.

places.name: Ravensbourne River
places.description: This was a tributary of the Thames and the now-non-existent Grand Surrey Canal.

persons.name: AlessandroVolta
persons.description: Professor of experimental physics at the University of Pavia. At the end of the eighteenth century he Invented the Voltaic pile which produced electric current and which Davy shortly dubbed the battery. Davy described meeting him in 1814 in notebook 14/I, p.38. ForMemRSL.

places.name: Loftus Alum Works
places.description: An alum works in North Yorkshire, near to Loftus and Staithes.

persons.name: WilliamAllen
persons.description: Allen was a Quaker who worked in the pharmaceutical industry. Davy asked him to give lectures on natural philosophy at the RI. FRSL.

persons.name: WilliamFeetham
persons.description: Ironmonger and maker of apparatus of 296 Oxford Street. Described as having a workshop at the Royal Institution, annexed to the laboratory.

persons.name: RichardKnight
persons.description: Brother of George who were both scientific instrument makers based in Foster Lane, Cheapside, London.

persons.name: AndreasLibavius
persons.description: German physician and alchemist and chemist.

persons.name: AndreasLibavius
persons.description: German physician and alchemist and chemist.

persons.name: Daniel GabrielFahrenheit
persons.description: German physicist, inventor, and scientific instrument maker, who invented the mercury-in-glass thermometer. The temperature scale he proposed is named after him. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: AndreasLibavius
persons.description: German physician and alchemist and chemist.

persons.name: AndreasLibavius
persons.description: German physician and alchemist and chemist.

persons.name: Joseph LouisProust
persons.description: French analytical chemist. Author of the 1794 paper 'Researches on Prussian Blue', in which he first set down the law of definite proportions, or Proust's law, as it is commonly known.

persons.name: HenryCavendish
persons.description: A central figure in English natural philosophy and chemistry, among other research he determined the density of the earth and discovered what would later be named hydrogen. He was one of the people who helped appoint Davy to the Royal Institution. Following his death in 1810 Davy delivered a widely-quoted eulogy on Cavendish and later arranged for some of his apparatus to be transferred to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

persons.name: Allen & Howard
persons.description: The partnership of William Allen (1770-1843) and Luke Howard (1772-1864), from whom Davy bought chemicals and apparatus.

persons.name: GilbertBlane
persons.description: Scottish physician who instituted health reform in the Royal Navy. Blane saw action against both the French and Spanish fleets, and later served as a Commissioner on the Sick and Wounded Board of the Admiralty. FRSL.

persons.name: ThomasThomson
persons.description: Scottish chemist and mineralogist whose writings contributed to the early spread of Dalton's atomic theory. FRSL.

persons.name: ThomasThomson
persons.description: Scottish chemist and mineralogist whose writings contributed to the early spread of Dalton's atomic theory. FRSL.

persons.name: WilsonLowry
persons.description: An engraver for scientific publications and a founder of the Geological Society of London. FRSL.

persons.name: Daniel GabrielFahrenheit
persons.description: German physicist, inventor, and scientific instrument maker, who invented the mercury-in-glass thermometer. The temperature scale he proposed is named after him. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Daniel GabrielFahrenheit
persons.description: German physicist, inventor, and scientific instrument maker, who invented the mercury-in-glass thermometer. The temperature scale he proposed is named after him. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Allen & Howard
persons.description: The partnership of William Allen (1770-1843) and Luke Howard (1772-1864), from whom Davy bought chemicals and apparatus.

persons.name: RobertBoyle
persons.description: Irish-born chemist and one of the founders of modern chemistry. FRSL.

persons.name: ThomasThomson
persons.description: Scottish chemist and mineralogist whose writings contributed to the early spread of Dalton's atomic theory. FRSL.

persons.name: ThomasThomson
persons.description: Scottish chemist and mineralogist whose writings contributed to the early spread of Dalton's atomic theory. FRSL.

persons.name: WilliamAllen
persons.description: Allen was a Quaker who worked in the pharmaceutical industry. Davy asked him to give lectures on natural philosophy at the RI. FRSL.

persons.name: ThomasThomson
persons.description: Scottish chemist and mineralogist whose writings contributed to the early spread of Dalton's atomic theory. FRSL.

persons.name: Allen & Howard
persons.description: The partnership of William Allen (1770-1843) and Luke Howard (1772-1864), from whom Davy bought chemicals and apparatus.

persons.name: WilliamAllen
persons.description: Allen was a Quaker who worked in the pharmaceutical industry. Davy asked him to give lectures on natural philosophy at the RI. FRSL.

persons.name: CharlesHatchett
persons.description: He made his money from coach building which he used to pursue his interests in chemistry and mineralogy in the course of which he isolated the chemical element now called niobium. He was a Manager of the Royal Institution, playing a key role especially in running its lecture programme during the 1800s. FRSL.

persons.name: William ThomasBrande
persons.description: Originally trained as an apothecary, Brande became a chemist. With Davy and others founded the Animal Chemistry Club. Lectured on chemistry in various London institutions and, following Davy's retirement succeeded him in his positions at the Royal Institution where he founded The Quarterly Journal of Science. A Secretary of the Royal Society of London, 1816-1826; later fell out with Davy. FRSL.

persons.name: AndreasLibavius
persons.description: German physician and alchemist and chemist.

persons.name: ThomasThomson
persons.description: Scottish chemist and mineralogist whose writings contributed to the early spread of Dalton's atomic theory. FRSL.

persons.name: AndreasLibavius
persons.description: German physician and alchemist and chemist.

persons.name: John GeorgeChildren
persons.description: English chemist, mineralogist, and zoologist, and a friend of Davy's. Children invented a method to extract silver from ore without the need for mercury. FRSL.

persons.name: JosephBanks
persons.description: A member of the Lincolnshire gentry, Banks sailed as a botanist on James Cook's first voyage to the Pacific (1768-1771). Elected President of the Royal Society of London in 1778 he served for forty-two years until just before his death. The dominant figure in the running of English science during that time, he became one of Davy's patrons and ultimately Davy succeeded him to the Presidency. FRSL.

persons.name: WilliamAllen
persons.description: Allen was a Quaker who worked in the pharmaceutical industry. Davy asked him to give lectures on natural philosophy at the RI. FRSL.

persons.name: Daniel GabrielFahrenheit
persons.description: German physicist, inventor, and scientific instrument maker, who invented the mercury-in-glass thermometer. The temperature scale he proposed is named after him. ForMemRSL.

places.name: River Wye
places.description: The River Wye is the fourth-longest river in the UK, stretching from its source on Plynlimon in mid-Wales to the Severn Estuary. For much of its length the river forms part of the border between England and Wales.

persons.name: HenryWarburton
persons.description: A member of the Animal Chemistry Club, the Chemical Club, and the Geological Society of London, and a sporting friend of Davy's. FRSL.

persons.name: GeorgePearson
persons.description: Physician and chemist who introduced a new systematic nomenclature for inorganic chemistry in English based on that devised by French chemists and confirmed the effacy of vaccination. FRSL.

persons.name: JohnNewman
persons.description: Scientific instrument maker of Lisle Street, and afterwards of Regent-street. Instrument maker to the Royal Institution who made the earliest Davy safety lamps.

persons.name: Allen & Howard
persons.description: The partnership of William Allen (1770-1843) and Luke Howard (1772-1864), from whom Davy bought chemicals and apparatus.

persons.name: WilliamAllen
persons.description: Allen was a Quaker who worked in the pharmaceutical industry. Davy asked him to give lectures on natural philosophy at the RI. FRSL.

places.name: Japan
places.description: an island country in East Asia. It is in the northwest Pacific Ocean.
